did.head: Descriptive Summary
did.unittitle: Grayson County (Va.) Board of Supervisors Records, 1891-1972 (bulk 1965-1972)
did.physloc: State Records Center - Archives Annex, Library of Virginia

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Grayson County (Va.) Board of Supervisors Records, 1891-1972 (bulk 1965-1972). Local government Records collection, Grayson County Court Records. The Library of Virginia, Richmond, Va. 23219.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: These items came to the Library of Virginia in a shipment of court papers from Grayson County.

bioghist.head: Historical Information
bioghist.p: Grayson County was named for William Grayson, a delegate to the Continental Congress from 1784 to 1787 and one of the first two United States senators from Virginia. It was formed from Wythe County in 1792, and a part of Patrick County was added in 1810.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Grayson County (Va.) Board of Supervisors Records, 1891-1972 (bulk 1965-1972) contains Minutes consisting of papers and correspondence for the years 1965-1972. This collection also includes a record of Witnesses Before the Board of Supervisors (1905), Road Books (1891, 1902-1903), highway and road papers (1931-1945), and papers and correspondences related to the Catawba Sanatorium (1936-1938), Southwestern State Hospital (1936-1937), Virginia Emergency Relief Administration (1934-1936), and Virginia Home for Incurables (1936).

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: Additional Grayson County Court Records can be found on microfilm at the Library of Virginia. Consult "A Guide to Virginia County and City Records on Microfilm"

did.unittitle: Road Book and Witnesses Before Board of Supervisors, 1891-1905 (bulk 1902-1903)

scopecontent.p: The Road Book includes records for 1891 and 1902-1903. The Witnesses Before Board of Supervisors includes records for 1905.

These records are correspondences, papers, agendas, and meeting minutes that relate to budgets, ordinances, Catawba Sanatorium (1936-1938), highways and roads (1931-1945), Southwestern State Hospital (1936-1937), Virginia Emergency Relief Administration (1934-1936), and Virginia Home for Incurables (1936).
These records are minutes which consists of papers and correspondence.
